title: Evolution in a big city - Jason Munshi-South

multiple-choice.question: What is the main topic of the lecture?

options.label: A
options.text: They are found in large populations throughout the city

options.label: B
options.text: They are stuck on a single hillside in Northern Manhattan

options.label: D
options.text: They are not native to the city

options.label: A
options.text: How to adapt to urban environments

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: D

options.label: D

options.text: It reduced the cost of shipping goods

options.label: C

title: Poetic stickup: Put the financial aid in the bag - Carvens Lissaint

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's main goal in the given scenario?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide financial aid to students

options.label: B
options.text: To protest the lack of financial aid for students

options.label: C
options.text: To demonstrate a hypothetical scenario of financial aid distribution

options.label: D
options.text: To provide a lesson on financial literacy

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Run all the financial aid and put it in a bag

options.label: B
options.text: That it is too difficult to get financial aid

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: To expose the flaws in the financial aid system

options.label: C
options.text: To persuade the audience to take action against the financial aid system

options.label: D
options.text: To provide a solution to the financial aid problem

options.label: A
options.text: A historical event that led to the abolition of slavery

options.label: B
options.text: A historical event that led to the oppression of African Americans

options.label: C
options.text: A reference to the idea that the financial aid system is designed to keep African Americans in debt

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: That it is a necessary evil

options.label: B
options.text: That it is a system designed to fail students

options.label: C
options.text: That it is a system that provides equal opportunities for all

options.label: D
options.text: That it is a system that is not necessary for students

options.label: A
options.text: To support the financial aid system

options.label: B
options.text: To take action against the financial aid system

options.label: C
options.text: To provide a solution to the financial aid problem

options.label: D
options.text: To persuade the audience to take action on their own

title: The power of simple words - Terin Izil

multiple-choice.question: Who wrote the novel "The Wizard of Oz"?
According to the author, why do ten-dollar words often fail?

options.label: B
options.text: They are not understood by the audience

options.label: C
options.text: They are not used by famous people

options.label: D
options.text: They are not used in literature

options.label: A
options.text: That bigger words are always better

options.label: B
options.text: That bigger words are not always better

options.label: C
options.text: That words should be used in every piece of literature

options.label: D
options.text: That words should be used in no piece of literature

options.label: A
options.text: That ten-dollar words are more effective

options.label: B
options.text: That simpler words are more effective

options.label: C
options.text: That it doesn't matter which type of word is used

options.label: D
options.text: That the comparison is not relevant

options.label: A
options.text: Finding the right words to use

options.label: B
options.text: Capturing the attention of the audience

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's suggestion for dealing with the challenge of capturing the audience's attention?

options.label: A
options.text: Using more words to describe things

options.label: B
options.text: Using simpler words to get the point across

options.label: D
options.text: Using the same 50 words to fill pages

According to the author, what is the relationship between the use of ten-dollar words and the audience's understanding?

options.label: A
options.text: The audience will automatically understand ten-dollar words

options.label: B
options.text: The audience will not understand ten-dollar words

options.label: C
options.text: The use of ten-dollar words has no effect on the audience's understanding

options.label: D
options.text: The audience will understand ten-dollar words if they are used correctly

multiple-choice.question: The author mentions that variety is the spice of life, but brevity is its bread and butter. What is the author's point about this statement?

options.label: A
options.text: That variety is more important than brevity

options.label: B
options.text: That brevity is more important than variety

options.label: C
options.text: That both variety and brevity are equally important

options.label: D
options.text: That the statement has no relevance to writing

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's final suggestion about using ten-dollar words?

options.label: A
options.text: To use them in every piece of writing

options.label: B
options.text: To use them sparingly and only when necessary

options.label: C
options.text: To save money and buy a Scrabble board

options.label: D
options.text: To use them to fill pages with 50 words

title: Symbiosis: A surprising tale of species cooperation - David Gonzales

multiple-choice.question: What is symbiosis?

options.label: A
options.text: A process where one species harms another.

options.label: B
options.text: A partnership between two different species.

options.label: C
options.text: A relationship where one species eats another.

options.label: D
options.text: A competition between two different species.

multiple-choice.question: Which bird is involved in a symbiotic relationship with the whitebark pine?
What do whitebark pine cones contain that is essential for other species?
What is unique about the way Clark's nutcrackers store seeds?

options.label: A
options.text: They bury them in large piles.

options.label: B
options.text: They store them in a pouch in their throat.

options.label: C
options.text: They leave them in the ground.

multiple-choice.question: How do Clark's nutcrackers remember where they cached seeds?

options.label: B
options.text: They use landmarks on the landscape.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of how Clark's nutcrackers and whitebark pines have evolved to suit each other?

options.label: A
options.text: Clark's nutcrackers have developed long beaks to extract seeds from cones.

options.label: B
options.text: Whitebark pines have developed short branches to make it harder for nutcrackers to reach the cones.

options.label: C
options.text: Clark's nutcrackers have developed short beaks to make it harder for them to reach the cones.

options.label: D
options.text: Whitebark pines have developed long branches to make it easier for nutcrackers to reach the cones.

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of the symbiotic relationship between Clark's nutcrackers and whitebark pines?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows the nutcrackers to have a source of food.

options.label: B
options.text: It allows the whitebark pines to have a source of water.

options.label: C
options.text: It allows both species to benefit and thrive.

options.label: D
options.text: It allows the nutcrackers to harm the whitebark pines.

multiple-choice.question: How do Clark's nutcrackers use their knowledge of the landscape to cache seeds?

options.label: B
options.text: They use landmarks on the landscape to triangulate to caches.

options.label: D
options.text: They don't use any knowledge of the landscape.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the symbiotic relationship between Clark's nutcrackers and whitebark pines?
What is an example of how Clark's nutcrackers have adapted to their environment to survive?

options.label: A
options.text: They have developed long beaks to extract seeds from cones.

options.label: B
options.text: They have developed short beaks to make it harder for them to reach the cones.

options.label: C
options.text: They have developed a source of water.

options.label: D
options.text: They have developed a source of food.

title: How many universes are there? - Chris Anderson

According to the transcript, what is the number of dimensions in which the multiverse is thought to exist?

What is the estimated number of atoms in our observable universe, if each atom has its own universe and all of the atoms in all of those universes each have their own universe, and this process is repeated for two more cycles?
According to the transcript, what is the number of dimensions in which the space-time continuum is thought to be infinite?
What is the estimated number of pocket universes that exist in the space-time continuum, according to some physicists?
According to the transcript, what is the theory that has been proven true beyond all doubt but is difficult to interpret?
What is the range of possible answers to the question of how many universes there are, according to the transcript?

title: How simple ideas lead to scientific discoveries - Adam Savage

multiple-choice.question: Who is credited with discovering the Earth's spherical shape using a simple observation?
What did Richard Feynman's father tell him was the name that scientists give to the phenomenon of the ball going to the back of the wagon?    - A: Gravity
According to Eratosthenes, what was the circumference of the Earth?    - A: 25,000 miles
What did Armand Fizeau use to send discrete pulses of light in his experiment to determine the speed of light?    - A: A laser
What was the distance between the two experimental stations set up by Armand Fizeau in Paris?    - A: 5 miles
What was the main contribution of Eratosthenes to science?    - A: He discovered the Earth's spherical shape

options.label: B
options.text: He calculated the circumference of the Earth

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the soul of science?    - A: The discovery of new facts

options.label: B
options.text: The confirmation of other people's results

multiple-choice.question: What did Armand Fizeau use to calculate the speed of light in his experiment?    - A: The distance between the two stations and the number of notches in the wheel

options.label: B
options.text: The speed of his wheel and the number of notches in the wheel

options.label: C
options.text: The distance between the two stations and the speed of his wheel

options.label: D
options.text: The number of notches in the wheel and the speed of his wheel and the distance between the two stations

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the main difference between science and other fields of study?    - A: Science is a closed, black box

options.label: B
options.text: Science is a field of study that requires curiosity and critical thinking

options.label: C

options.label: D
